header.title: New Dimensions for the CUBE of SPACE: The Path of Initiation Revealed by the Tarot upon the Qabalistic Cube

central_thesis: David Allen Hulse presents a unique, operative interpretation of the Qabalistic Cube of Space by systematically correlating its 22 dimensions with the Major Arcana tarot cards. Building upon the foundational work of Paul Foster Case and the Sepher Yetzirah, Hulse reveals a comprehensive 'Path of Initiation'â€”a sequential journey of spiritual evolution and self-realization that guides the practitioner from a 'sleeper' to an 'ascended master' through meditation and engagement with the cube's symbolic directions and their associated tarot archetypes.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part One: Introduction to the Cube of Space
structure_content.summary: This section introduces the Cube of Space as a cosmological model rooted in the Sepher Yetzirah, a foundational Jewish mystical text. It explains the cube's structure, comprising a center, six faces, and twelve edges, which correspond to Hebrew letters, astrological symbols, and the 22 Major Arcana tarot cards. Hulse highlights Paul Foster Case's pioneering work in identifying the three 'Mother Letters' (Aleph, Mem, Shin) with the cube's crucial interior dimensions, thus completing the symbolic framework. The importance of constructing a physical model and meditating on these correspondences for visualization is emphasized.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part Two: The Path of Initiation Around the Cube of Space
structure_content.summary: This part details the core 'Path of Initiation' (also called the 'Path of Return'), a symbolic journey of spiritual evolution across the Cube of Space. It describes seven sequential 'grades' of initiation, starting from the 'sleeper' on the Western face and progressing through 'seeker' (North), 'initiate' (South), 'teacher' (East), 'master of light' (Above), and 'master of darkness' (Below), culminating in the 'ascended master' at the Cube's center. Each grade and its five steps (one central face card, four bordering edge cards) are explored, explaining the spiritual experiences, challenges, and transformations encountered by the soul as it traverses the cube, particularly noting the divergent paths of 'The Saint' and 'The Godhead' available to the 'teacher'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part Three: Further Comments on the Cube of Space
structure_content.summary: This section contextualizes Hulse's interpretation by discussing the contributions of other Qabalistic and occult scholars, including Paul Foster Case, Gareth Knight, Robert Wang, and Aryeh Kaplan, detailing their perspectives and Case's unique attributions regarding the interior dimensions and directional poles. It also broadens the scope by drawing parallels between the Cube of Space's symbolism and other esoteric traditions. Topics include the solar cycle, the four elements, the Archangels of the four quarters, the eight sacred directions of the Chinese I-Ching, the Tibetan Wheel of Rebirth, and the cube's significance as a sacred temple in Judaism, Freemasonry, Alchemy (Philosopher's Stone), and Eastern traditions (Jewel in the Lotus), underscoring its universal mystical relevance.

key_concepts.definition: A Qabalistic cosmological diagram derived from the Sepher Yetzirah, representing a three-dimensional model of the universe. It consists of 22 dimensions (1 center, 6 faces, 12 edges, 3 interior axes) mapped to the 22 letters of the Hebrew alphabet, astrological forces, and the 22 Major Arcana tarot cards. It serves as a symbolic roadmap for spiritual evolution and self-realization.

The sequential spiritual journey undertaken by the soul through the Cube of Space. It encompasses seven 'grades' of awareness and development, leading from a state of unconsciousness ('sleeper') to complete enlightenment and union with the divine ('ascended master'). This path involves meditating on and integrating the lessons of the tarot archetypes associated with each direction and dimension of the cube.

In Hulse's system, these Hebrew letters correspond to the three interior axes of the Cube of Space: Aleph (Air) connects Above-Below (The Fool), Mem (Water) connects East-West (The Hanged Man), and Shin (Fire) connects North-South (Judgement). These elemental paths are crucial for understanding the cube's interior dimensions and the process of cosmic consciousness, birth/rebirth, and spiritual awakening.

Distinct stages of spiritual development encountered along the Path of Initiation, each associated with a specific face or the center of the Cube of Space. These are: 1. Sleeper (West), 2. Seeker (North), 3. Initiate (South), 4. Teacher (East), 5. Master of Light (Above), 6. Master of Darkness (Below), and 7. Ascended Master (Center). Each grade involves mastering specific lessons and overcoming spiritual obstacles.

Represents the higher self, the essential, constant spiritual identity of an individual, and the cosmic traveler who emanates into and returns from incarnations. On the Cube of Space, The Fool is the central axis connecting Above to Below, symbolizing the path of cosmic consciousness and the merging of the lower and higher selves. It is the beginning point of the journey into physical manifestation and the return to the source.

Located at the exact center of the Cube of Space, it symbolizes the cosmos, the unified self, and the ultimate destination of the Path of Initiation. Governed by Saturn and associated with the element Earth (as a blend of Air, Water, Fire), The World represents the state of complete illumination and the final grade of the 'ascended master' who has transcended physical incarnation and now guides others.

A personal spiritual guide assigned to an individual's current incarnation, distinct from the higher self. Its function is to lead the lower self to the realization of the higher self. On the Cube of Space, Temperance occupies the West Above position, representing the first direct contact with the spiritual world and prompting an awakening from spiritual slumber.

An alchemical symbol of the perfected self, represented as a cubic stone. It signifies the transformation of base matter (lower self) into gold (spiritual perfection) through intense spiritual work and purification. Paul Foster Case's Builders of the Adytum uses this cubic stone as its emblem, emblazoned with symbols for Salt, Sulfur, and Mercury on its faces.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined by Hulse is a method of self-initiation and spiritual development achieved by consciously traversing the symbolic landscape of the Qabalistic Cube of Space. The practitioner constructs or visualizes a three-dimensional cube adorned with the 22 Major Arcana tarot cards, each corresponding to a specific Hebrew letter, astrological force, and directional dimension (center, faces, edges, interior axes). The 'Path of Initiation' guides the aspirant through seven 'grades' of awareness and experience, sequentially exploring the cube's dimensions, meditating on the associated tarot archetypes, and integrating their symbolic lessons. This operative process aims to progressively awaken the higher self, reconcile internal dualities, and ultimately achieve a state of complete spiritual illumination.
tools: Three-Dimensional Model of the Cube of Space: A physical cutout model (p.151) is recommended for tangible interaction and visualization practice.
Paul Foster Case B.O.T.A. Tarot Deck: Explicitly recommended for its precise symbolic alignment with the Cube of Space, although other decks (e.g., Waite-Smith) can be used as substitutes (p.14).
Qabalistic Correspondences Tables: Tables detailing Hebrew letters, astrological attributes, directions, and tarot cards (e.g., Table 1, p.22) are essential for correct mapping.
Meditation and Visualization Skills: Fundamental for internalizing the cube's structure, the tarot archetypes, and their dynamic interplay as the soul progresses along the initiatory path.
rituals: Construction and Visualization of the Cube: The core practice involves physically constructing a 3D model of the Cube of Space from the provided diagram (p.151) and/or visualizing it mentally. The 22 Major Arcana cards are affixed or imagined in their precise locations, along with their assigned colors and directions (as detailed in Table 1, p.22 and Table 2, p.25).

Traversal of the Path of Initiation: The practitioner follows a predefined sequence of steps through the cube, beginning as a 'sleeper' in the West and moving through the faces of North, South, East, Above, Below, and finally reaching the 'ascended master' state at the Center (Table 13, p.149). Each step involves meditating on the specific tarot card, its symbolism, and its corresponding direction/element/planet.

Engagement with Interior Dimensions: Active contemplation of the three elemental interior axes (The Fool: Above-Below/Air, The Hanged Man: East-West/Water, Judgement: North-South/Fire) is critical for deeper understanding of cosmic consciousness, birth/rebirth, and spiritual transformation (p.39, 115).

Conscious Choice of Paths: At advanced stages, particularly for the 'teacher' on the Eastern face, a ritualistic choice is made between the 'Path of the Saint' (returning to serve humanity) and the 'Path to the Godhead' (direct union with the divine), involving specific internal commitments and external actions (p.90-93).

relevant_quotes.text: THIS BOOK CONTAINS a bold new look at the symbolic meanings of the first twenty-two cards of the tarot deck. Known as the Major Arcana (Greater Secrets), these twenty-two cards correspond to the twenty-two letters of the Hebrew alphabet and are numbered from 0 through 21 (often with Roman numerals).

If at all possible, try to construct a three-dimensional model of the Cube of Space. The figure printed at the end of this book is, in fact, a cube laid out on a flat plane as a cross of six squares. It can be cut out and used as a model. First, cut out the cross, preserving the white tabs on its edges. Then, fold it to form a perfect cube, gluing the tabs to the faces they touch. Creating such a model by hand will greatly facilitate the visualization required to completely understand the symbolic meaning behind each of the twenty-two directions of space as delineated by the cube.

This cube of letters cannot reveal its deepest secrets, however, until it is clothed in the cards of the tarot. Then, and only then, can this mystical cube speak directly to our souls and show us the way, which is the true path of initiation we all must eventually travel.

The Cube of Space is a powerful Qabalistic map because it tells a very simple, yet glorious message in the tarot cards that adorn its alphabetical dimensions. We will all eventually become our own teacher.

These three interior coordinates, water unites East and West, being the symbolic path of birth. Fire unites North and South, being the path of spiritual rebirth. Air unites Above and Below, being the path of cosmic consciousness that allows a total merging of the lower self (our everyday, normal point of view) with the higher self (the vantage point of heightened spiritual awareness).

critical_analysis.relevance: Hulse's 'New Dimensions for the Cube of Space' is a highly relevant and valuable contribution to Western esoteric literature, particularly for practitioners of Qabalah and Tarot. It elaborates on Paul Foster Case's pioneering integration of the Major Arcana with the Qabalistic Cube of Space, offering a detailed and systematic 'Path of Initiation' that was previously less articulated. The book's strength lies in its meticulous mapping of spiritual evolution across the cube's 22 dimensions, linking Hebrew letters, astrological forces, and tarot archetypes into a coherent, experiential system. Hulse provides a practical framework for self-initiation, moving beyond mere theoretical correspondences to an operative method of inner transformation. His work contextualizes the Cube within broader esoteric traditions, drawing insightful parallels with Masonic, alchemical, Chinese I-Ching, and Tibetan Buddhist concepts, enriching its universal appeal and demonstrating its profound philosophical depth. This makes it an essential text for understanding a practical application of the Cube of Space model for spiritual growth.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This book is primarily intended for serious students and practitioners of Western Esotericism, particularly those engaged with Qabalah, Hermeticism, and Tarot as tools for spiritual development. It will appeal to adherents of Paul Foster Case's Builders of the Adytum (B.O.T.A.) tradition, as well as individuals interested in self-initiation, mystical visualization, and symbolic cosmology. Readers seeking a deeply structured and sequential approach to personal enlightenment, and those who desire to integrate diverse esoteric wisdom traditions, will find this a compelling and practical manual. It is less suited for beginners to occultism or those solely interested in predictive Tarot, given its focus on complex symbolic synthesis and active inner work.
